highlights.note: Objective imponderable: Objective imponderables are philosophical entities or properties that are claimed to exist independently of human minds and yet cannot be fully measured, quantified, or directly observed. Debates about them focus on whether such features (for example, values, intrinsic qualities, or certain metaphysical truths) can be known objectively or are necessarily beyond empirical confirmation. Critics argue that invoking objective imponderables risks unverifiable metaphysics, while proponents maintain they are necessary to account for aspects of reality that resist reduction to measurable terms.

highlights.text:
It seems perfectly transparent to me that my enemies, my friends and the general public allegedly do not understand the meaning of the images that arise and that I transcribe into my paintings. How can anyone expect them to understand when I myself, the “maker,” don’t understand my paintings either. The fact that I myself, at the moment of painting, do not understand their meaning doesn’t imply that these paintings are meaningless: on the contrary, their meaning is so deep, complex, coherent, and involuntary that it eludes the simple analysis of logical intuition.

In order to reduce my paintings to the level of the vernacular and explain them, I should have to submit them to special analyses, preferably of a scientific rigor and as ambitiously objective as possible. After all, any explanation occurs *a posteriori*, once the painting exists as a phenomenon.
the world of concrete irrationality may be as objectively evident, consistent, durable, as persuasively, cognoscitively, and communicably thick as the exterior world of phenomenal reality.
the irrational concrete subject. The pictorial means of expression are concentrated on the subject.

the most analytically narrative and discredited academicism, can become sublime hierarchies of thought when combined with new exactness of concrete irrationality as the images of concrete irrationality approach the phenomenal Real, the corresponding means of expression approach those of great realist painting — Velasquez and Vermeer de Delft — to paint realistically in accordance with irrational thinking and the unknown imagination.
highlights.note: Velázquez and Vermeer’s influence on surrealist “concrete irrationality” painting: Velázquez’s rich realism and complex spatial arrangements, together with Vermeer’s precise light, quiet interiors, and meticulous surfaces, provided surrealist artists with tools to make dreamlike scenes feel convincingly real. Surrealists adapted these techniques to present impossible juxtapositions and illogical narratives as if they were ordinary, creating a tension between believable detail and irrational content that critics called “concrete irrationality.” This blend encouraged viewers to accept paradoxical images as tangible, deepening surrealism’s exploration of the unconscious and everyday reality.

highlights.note: Anal wheelbarrow: The Anal wheelbarrow is a surrealist performance object used in avant-garde art and theater, often designed to provoke, challenge social norms, and explore themes of body, power, and absurdity. Typically constructed as a modified wheelbarrow or cart incorporating suggestive shapes or interactive elements, it is employed in staged actions where performers use it to create striking, disorienting visual effects and symbolic gestures. Its use and interpretation vary widely, with critics and audiences debating whether it functions as satire, transgression, or conceptual commentary within the broader context of surrealist and performance art.

highlights.text:
THE CONQUEST OF THE IRRATIONAL

by Salvador Dali

The flagrant lack of philosophic and general culture in the cheerful propellers of that model of mental deficiency that calls itself abstract art, abstraction-creation, nonfigurative art, etc., is one of the authentically sweetest things from the viewpoint of the intellectual and “modern” desolation of our era.

Furthermore, the images obtained offer two serious inconveniences: (1) they cease being unknown images, because by falling into the realm of psychoanalysis they are easily reduced to current and logical speech albeit continuing to offer an uninterpretable residue and a very vast and authentic margin of enigma, especially for the greater public; (2) their essentially virtual and chimerical character no longer satisfies our desires or our “principles of verification” first announced by Breton in his Discourse on the Smidgen of Reality. Ever since, the frenzied images of Surrealism desperately tend toward their tangible possibility, their objective and physical existence in reality. Only those people who are unaware of this can still flounder about in the gross misunderstanding of the “poetic escape,” and continue to believe our mysticism of the fantastic and our fanaticism of the marvelous. I, for my part, believe that the era of inaccessible mutilations, unrealizable bloodthirsty osmoses, flying visceral lacerations, hair-rocks, catastrophic uprootings, is over as far as experimentation goes, although this era may quite probably continue to constitute the exclusive iconography of a large period of surrounding Surrealist painting. The new frenzied images of concrete irrationality tend toward their real and physical “possibility”; they go beyond the domain of psychoanalyzable “virtual” hallucinations and manifestations.
highlights.note:
Dali says early Surrealist methods (dreams, free association, etc.) produce images with two problems:  
1) Once psychoanalyzed, they’re no longer truly “unknown”; they can be translated into normal language.  
2) They stay “virtual” and unreal, which no longer satisfies Surrealism’s need for real, verifiable impact.  

So he argues Surrealism must move on to “concrete irrationality”: bizarre images that exist physically in reality, not just in the mind.

highlights.text: Contrary to dream memory, and the virtual and impossible images of purely receptive states, “which one can only narrate,” it is the physical facts of “objective” irrationality with which one can really hurt oneself.
highlights.note: Unlike memories of dreams or strange images you only see when you’re passive and can only describe afterward, real harm comes from actual irrational actions or facts in the real world — the concrete, “objective” mistakes or dangerous choices you make that can truly hurt you.
